channel.title: Oh Man, More Neb Issues
channel.description:
Ok, this is a long one. I'm lacking enough prerequisites to piss people off though.
So, this is what I want to do: I want to take my SMF cookie and use it on my home page for simple things like "Wecome USERNAME."
So, to do this I have to use a regular expression to find the user id and then I have to test that against a SQL daterbace. This runs me into a couple problems. I don't know how to get the selection from ereg(i), and I know nothing about MySQL and PHP-MySQL interaction.
So, if you can help me out with that. It has to search through something like this: [code] a:4:{i:0;s:1:\"1\";i:1;s:40:\"LolPassWordHash\";i:2;i:1354385269;i:3;i:0;}[/code] I have to find the \"1\" and then test the number against the MySQL daterbace.

item.title: Oh Man, More Neb Issues

To piss people off that are trying to use them?

item.title: Oh Man, More Neb Issues

item.description:
@Bang_Train wrote:

wow ive messed wit cookies but never serialized them

interesting…

is there something beneficial to serializing them?

Read full topic

item.title: Oh Man, More Neb Issues
item.dc:creator: @pkedpker pkedpker
item.description:
@pkedpker wrote:

well this works…

<?php $sObject3 = stripslashes('a:4:{i:0;s:1:\"1\";i:1;s:40:\"LolPassWordHash\";i:2;i:1354385269;i:3;i:0;}'); print_r( __unserialize($sObject3 )); function __unserialize($sObject) { $__ret =preg_replace('!s:(\d+):"(.*?)";!e', "'s:'.strlen('$2').':\"$2\";'", $sObject ); return unserialize($__ret); } ?>

output:

Array ( [0] => 1 [1] => LolPassWordHash [2] => 1354385269 [3] => 0 )

ya it works 100% just tested on my webserver make sure to wrap the string with stripslashes and quotes
if your array is like $Whatever you would do $Whatever[0] to return the 1

Read full topic

item.title: Oh Man, More Neb Issues
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

Ok, this is a long one. I’m lacking enough prerequisites to piss people off though.

So, this is what I want to do:
I want to take my SMF cookie and use it on my home page for simple things like “Wecome USERNAME.”

So, to do this I have to use a regular expression to find the user id and then I have to test that against a SQL daterbace.
This runs me into a couple problems. I don’t know how to get the selection from ereg(i), and I know nothing about MySQL and PHP-MySQL interaction.

So, if you can help me out with that.
It has to search through something like this:

a:4:{i:0;s:1:\"1\";i:1;s:40:\"LolPassWordHash\";i:2;i:1354385269;i:3;i:0;}
I have to find the “1” and then test the number against the MySQL daterbace.

Read full topic
